Description: String of beads: green glazed steatite, shell, bone, coral, nenta shell and shell hippopotamus amulet. Amuletic string with pendant: from the disturbed burial of a child, composed of many disc beads of various sizes and short cylindrical beads of shell; the ribbed long cylinders are 'Dentalium' shell tubes. The other short cylindrical beads are of bone and green glazed steatite. The long cylindrical beads are of bone, the drop-shaped pendant of ivory, and the hippopotamus amulet of shell. The hippopotamus stands with its feet joined together as though tied; it is pierced from front to back between its forelegs and hind legs for stringing. A large 'Nerita' shell completes the string.
Curator's comments: The hippopotamus is one of only two types of representational ornament known from the period; the other type is a gazelle's head. According to G. Brunton in ‘Mostagedda and the Tasian Culture’ (London, 1937), 85, Dentilium shell possibly to be re-identified as organ-coral. Cf. 1929,1015.167: green jasper hippopotamus amulet from Mostagedda, grave 1208, in G. Brunton ‘Mostagedda and the Tasian Culture’ (London, 1937), pl. XXII, 39; Bead corpus, pl. XXXIX, 21A2. Differences in the identification of materials are found in the primary publication: the hippopotamus amulet is described as bone: and ivory and turquoise are included among identified bead materials. Bibliography: G. Brunton & G. Caton-Thompson, ‘The Badarian Civilization’ (London, 1928), 16, 27; pl. VIII; Bead corpus, pls. XLIX-L; E. Massoulard, ‘Préhistoire et Protohistoire d’ Égypte’ (Paris, 1949), pl. XXXIV, 21; C. Andrews, 'Amulets of Ancient Egypt' (London 1994), p.9. G. Pinch, Magic in Ancient Egypt (London 1994), fig.1.
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1981 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities. Jewellery I (1)
Brunton & Caton-Thompson 1928 / The Badarian Civilisation and Predynastic Remains near Badari (p. 16, 27; pl. xxiv.15)
Acquisition name: Donated by: British School of Archaeology, Egypt
